{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Juan Francisco González | image = Juan Francisco Gonalez.jpg | imagesize =200 | caption = | birth_name = Juan Francisco González | birth_date = {{birth date |1853|09|25|}} | birth_place = [[Santiago]], [[Chile]] | death_date = {{death date|1933|03|04}} | death_place = [[Santiago]], [[Chile]] | nationality = [[Chile]]an | field = [[Painting]] | training = | movement = | works = ''Carretelas en la Vega'', ''Retrato de Augusto d'Halmar'', ''Callejon de San Fernando'' among others | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards =1884, 3rd Place, Salón de Santiago, Chile; 1890, 2nd Place, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile; 1892 Landscape Prize, Edwards Award, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile; 1896, 2nd Place, Valparaíso Municipality Exhibition, Chile; 1898 honourable mention, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile; 1900, 1st Place, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile; 1901 Landscape Prize, Edwards Award, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile; 1910, 2nd Place, [[Buenos Aires]] international Exhibition, [[Argentina]]; 1929, award winner at the Seville Hispano-American Exhibition, [[Spain]]; 1929, honourable mention, Edwards Award, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile; 1997, named most influential painter in Chile in a top ten ranking produced by a survey of a hundred thought leaders by the Cultural Corporation of [[Las Condes]], Santiago, Chile. }}
'''Juan Francisco González Escobar'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portaldearte.cl/autores/gonzalez.htm |title=Juan Francisco González |publisher=Portaldearte.cl |date=2011-01-19 |accessdate=2013-09-09}}</ref> ([[Santiago]], [[Chile]], September 25, 1853 – Santiago, March 4, 1933) is known as one of the four [[Chilean art#The Great Chilean Masters|Great Chilean Masters]] and as the archetypal romantic bohemian artist of the early 20th century. He was the most prolific of the Chilean masters, leaving an estimated 4,000 works, and was also notable for being one of Chile’s first [[Modern art|modern]] painters. He was seen as a symbol of the new creative generation that appeared in 20th century Chile, with a style highly influenced by impressionism and local elements. [[File:"Calle de Limache".jpg|thumb|"Calle de Limache" (Limache streets)]]
Right from the beginning, González worked in a free and flexible manner and did not stick rigidly to any particular techniques, giving him space to express his lively and restless personality. He took his attitude towards art as an attitude towards life and was considered by his successors as great example to follow.
As a master, González used to tell his students that to be a good painter, “first you must learn to observe and get excited about the colours and forms of nature, regardless of whether the picture and its details are accurate reflection of reality or not.”
==Biography== Juan Francisco González,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artistasplasticoschilenos.cl/biografia.aspx?itmid=323 |title=APCh www.artistasplasticoschilenos.cl |publisher=Artistasplasticoschilenos.cl |date= |accessdate=2013-09-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vamosviendo.cl/files/prologo-.pdf|publisher=Vamosviendo.cl|author=Isabel Cruz de Amenábar|title=Biography|language=es|accessdate=April 6, 2013}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> son of José González and Mercedes Escobar, grew up in [[Recoleta, Chile|Recoleta]], a neighborhood of [[Santiago]] that runs along the side of [[Cerro Blanco]] hill, where his family ran a business importing goods from [[Ecuador]]. As a child, his parents enrolled him in art classes with Chilean artist Manuel Tapia and when he was 14, by a strange twist of fate, he met [[Pedro Lira]], who would become another of the four Chilean masters. Lira, seeing that the boy had a bright future, recommended that he continue his career at the [[Chilean art#Chilean Academy of Painting|Chilean Academy of Painting]]. In 1869, aged 16, he entered the Academy, and was taught by the painters [[Ernesto Kirchbach]] and [[Juan Mochi]].
[[File:Carrera por J.F.Gonzalez.jpg|thumb|left|"Los Últimos momentos del General [[José Miguel Carrera]]” (The last moments of General José Miguel Carrera]] González’ style was initially quite similar to that of his teachers, but his work progressed during a trip to Europe. His visits to [[Spain]], [[Italy]], [[England]], [[France]] and [[Germany]] instilled in him a much more modern style of art than the traditional techniques he had learned in Chile. It was in [[France]] where he discovered [[Impressionism]], a movement he identified with very much. He incorporated many elements of Impressions into his own style, such as the focus on capturing light and an appreciation for landscape and for small canvases. On his return to Chile in 1906, his name started to become well-known after giving a lecture at the [[University of Chile]] and was appointed as a lecturer at the Academy of painting, teaching sketching and freehand drawing.
[[File:Retrato de Augusto d'Halmar.jpg|thumb| Augusto d'Halmar portrait]] After leaving his teaching job, he dedicated himself to painting again and began capturing the flowers and fruits of Chile using secure and calm brushstrokes, thick acrylic paint and rough textures that are characteristic of his work. Although some of his paintings are very small, González’ ability to communicate tastes and smells to the viewer is remarkable. He won several awards in Chile, including third prize at the 1884 Salón de Santiago exhibition, second prize at the 1890 Salón Oficial exhibition and first prize at the 1900 Salón Oficial.
González constantly sought freer expression through his painting, investigating and experimenting with his painting materials to achieve, for example, a transparency in [[oil paint]] that made it look similar to [[watercolor painting|watercolor]]. His skillful execution and sensitivity to atmosphere placed him alongside the community of young artists who revolutionized visual arts in 19th century [[Paris]]. His favorite subjects included peasants, [[adobe]] houses and flowers, handling with skill the movement and color of flowers, and his youthful spirit always kept him current. His most famous quotations include:
“Grace is not in truth itself, but in the personal expression of it. To draw is to express, drawing is like writing, so one should write as one thinks”. “Unlike the scientific method, which proceeds by analysis, art proceeds by synthesis”. “You must look quickly and with the eyes of the soul and heart”.
[[File:"Carretelas en la Vega".jpg|thumb|left|"Carretelas en la Vega"]]
The influence of González can be seen in the “[[Chilean art#The 13 Generation|Tragic Generation]]”, better known as the [[Generación del 13]], and the controversial “[[Chilean art#The Montparnasse Group|Montparnasse Group]]”. He himself was part of the literature group "Los Diez" (The Ten), who tried to live by balancing aesthetics and ethics, creative spirit and art, a philosophy which González maintained even after the group dissolved.
González died on March 4, 1933, and is considered to have changed the course of Chilean painting. Isabel Cruz González called him “the first modern Chilean painter” and said that “he left a mark like none other of his contemporaries, capturing on canvas the essence of Chilean popular life.” Throughout his career, until the day he died, he aimed for the maximum effect on the canvas, minimising and simplifying the themes, a characteristic that can be observed from his early landscapes to the still lifes he produced at the end of his life.
== Selected list of Juan Francisco González work == <gallery caption= widths="90px" heights="90px" perrow="6> File:"Sandias".jpg|"Sandias" File:Retrato del pintor Juan Francisco González .jpg|Retrato del pintor Juan Francisco González en su vejez (Portrait of the artist Juan Francisco González) File:"Callejon de San Fernando", Juan Francisco Gonzalez.jpg|"Callejon de San Fernando" (San Fernando Passage) File:"Mariana", Juan Francisco González.jpg|"Mariana" File:"Retrato de niña".jpg|"Retrato de niña" (Portrait of a girl) File:"Granadas".jpg|"Granadas" File:"El Niño Dormido".jpg|"El Niño Dormido" (Sleeping boy) File:"Calle de San Bernardo".jpg|"Calle de San Bernardo" (San Bernado Street) File:"Lucumas".jpg|"Lucumas" File:"Manzanas".jpg|"Manzanas" (Apples) File:"Nogales".jpg|"Nogales" (Walnuts) File:"Limachito".jpg|"Limachito" File:"Paisaje de rancho".jpg|"Paisaje de rancho" (Farm landscape) File:Basilica de Lourdes, Quinta Normal.jpg|Basílica de Lourdes, Quinta Normal File:Retrato de Rosario de Caviedes.jpg|Retrato de Rosario de Caviedes (Portrait of Rosario de Caviedes) File:"Membrillo".jpg|"Membrillo" (Quince) File:Retrato de el periodista Eloy Caviedes.jpg|Retrato de el periodista Eloy Caviedes (Portrait of the journalist Eloy Caviedes) File:"Retrato de Dama".jpg|"Retrato de Dama" (Portrait of a lady) </gallery>
==Awards== *1884 3rd Place, Salón de Santiago, Chile. *1890 2nd Place, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile. *1892 Landscape Prize, Edwards Award, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile. *1896 2nd Place, Valparaíso Municipality Exposition, Chile. *1898 Honourable Mention, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile. *1900 1st Place, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile. *1901 Landscape Prize, Edwards Award, Salón Oficial, Santiago, Chile. *1910 2ª Place, Buenos Aires International Exhibition, Argentina. *1929 award winner at the Seville Hispano-American Exhibition, Spain. *1929 Honourable Mention, Edwards Award, Salón Oficial. Santiago, Chile. *1997 named most influential painter in Chile in a top ten ranking produced by a survey of a hundred thought leaders by the Cultural Corporation of [[Las Condes]], Santiago, Chile

{{Infobox film | name = ''Just Like Heaven'' | image = Just like Heaven poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Mark Waters (director)|Mark Waters]] | producer = [[Walter F. Parkes]]
[[Laurie MacDonald]] | screenplay = {{ubl|[[Peter Tolan]]|[[Leslie Dixon]]}} | based on = {{based on|''[[If Only It Were True]]''|[[Marc Levy]]}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Reese Witherspoon]]|[[Mark Ruffalo]]}} | music = [[Rolfe Kent]] | cinematography = [[Daryn Okada]] | editing = [[Bruce Green]] | distributor = [[DreamWorks Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2005|09|16|}} | runtime = 95 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $58 million | gross = $102.8 million{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=justlikeheaven.htm |title = ''Just Like Heaven'' (2005) | publisher = [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate = 2010-12-20}} }} '''''Just Like Heaven''''' is a 2005 American [[romantic comedy]] [[fantasy film]] directed by [[Mark Waters (director)|Mark Waters]], starring [[Reese Witherspoon]], [[Mark Ruffalo]], and [[Jon Heder]]. It is based on the French novel ''[[If Only It Were True]]'' (''Et si c'était vrai...'') written by [[Marc Levy]]. [[Steven Spielberg]] obtained the rights to produce the film from the book.{{cite web | url = http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/386887.If_Only_It_Were_True | title = If Only It Were True (Et si c'était vrai #1) | publisher = Goodreads Inc.}} The film was released in the United States and Canada on September 16, 2005. ==Plot== Elizabeth Masterson (Witherspoon), a young emergency medicine physician whose work is her whole life, is in a serious car accident while on her way to a blind date. Three months later, David Abbott (Ruffalo), a landscape architect recovering from the sudden death of his wife, moves into the apartment that had been Elizabeth's, after 'discovering' it in what seems to be a fateful [[Wiktionary:happenstance#English|happenstance]]. Elizabeth's spirit begins to appear to David in the apartment with [[ghost]]ly properties and abilities that make it clear that something is not right. She can suddenly appear and disappear, walk or move through walls and objects, and once takes over his actions. When they meet, they are both surprised, as Elizabeth is still unaware of her recent history and refuses to think she is dead. David tries to have her spirit exorcised from the apartment, but to no avail. Since only David can see and hear her, others think that he is hallucinating and talking to himself. David and Elizabeth begin to bond, as much as that is possible, and he takes her out of town to a beautiful landscaped garden he designed. Elizabeth tells him she senses she has been there before, and in fact, the garden was something she was dreaming of in the opening scenes of the film, where she was awakened by a colleague from cat-napping after working a 23-hour shift in the hospital. Together, assisted by a psychic bookstore clerk, Darryl (Heder), Elizabeth and David find out who she is, what happened to her, and why they are connected. She is not dead, but in a [[coma]], her body being kept on [[life support]] at the hospital where she used to work. When David discovers that in accordance with her [[living will]], she will soon be allowed to die, he tries to prevent this by telling Elizabeth's sister, Abby, that he can see her and what the situation involves. One of Elizabeth's young nieces is revealed to be able to sense her presence as well. Abby thinks David is mentally disturbed and drives him out of her house. Desperate, David decides to prevent Elizabeth's death by stealing her from the hospital. He asks his friend/therapist Jack to help him, and Jack is found to be actually Abby's former college boyfriend, who had set up a blind date for David with Elizabeth on the night of the accident - the reason David can see Elizabeth is that they were meant to meet. He then admits to Jack and Elizabeth that he loves her and that is the reason he does not want her to die; he has gotten past the death of his wife. While stealing Elizabeth, they are quickly discovered in the hospital. The security guards find them, pulling Jack away from Elizabeth, but when he is grabbed, her breathing tube is removed. David gets away from the guards a bit longer, but Elizabeth is now dying. David frantically kisses the dying Elizabeth, breathing some air into her lungs, while her spirit begins to fade away. Then, amazingly, her heartbeat returns and she miraculously awakens from the coma. However, the recovered Elizabeth does not remember anything that happened during the coma or any of the events with David, who leaves the hospital in sadness. Sometime later, Elizabeth goes back to her apartment. She is drawn up to the roof of the building, which has been transformed into a beautiful landscaped garden. She finds David there, who has gotten in with a spare key Elizabeth's spirit had shown him. Just as he is about to leave, she asks for her key back. When their hands touch, her memory of the events during her coma are restored, and they kiss. ==Cast== * [[Reese Witherspoon]] as Dr. Elizabeth Masterson * [[Mark Ruffalo]] as David Abbott * [[Ivana Miličević]] as Katrina * [[Jon Heder]] as Darryl * [[Donal Logue]] as Jack *[[Dina Spybey|Dina Waters]] as Abby Brody * [[Rosalind Chao]] as Dr. Fran Lo * [[Ben Shenkman]] as Dr. Brett Rushton * [[Joel McKinnon Miller]] as Lead Ghostbuster * [[Caroline Aaron]] as Grace * [[Kerris Dorsey]] as Zoe Brody * Alyssa Shafer as Lily Brody * [[Willie Garson]] as Maitre D' ==Critical reception== Critics were mixed on the film. The film achieved a 56% approval rating from 149 reviews on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] and the consensus "Delightfully sweet like a lollipop, ''Just Like Heaven'' is a dreamy romantic comedy that may give you a toothache when it attempts to broach difficult end of life issues by throwing a cherry on top."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/just_like_heaven/|title=Just Like Heaven (2005)|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} However, the most prominent critics – such as [[Roger Ebert]], [[Richard Roeper]], and [[A. O. Scott]] – gave it favorable reviews; they all agreed that the plot had logical flaws that were somewhat overcome by good dialogue and characterization. The performances of Witherspoon, Ruffalo, and Heder were all generally well received. Heder's appearance helped to debunk an urban legend that the actor had died shortly after filming ''[[Napoleon Dynamite]]''.{{cite web |url= http://www.snopes.com/movies/actors/heder.asp|title=Napoleon Die-namite | publisher=[[Snopes.com]]|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} The DVD release in February 2006 was given unusually strong promotional publicity. ==Theme song== The title of this film is also that of a popular 1987 song, "[[Just Like Heaven (song)|Just Like Heaven]]" by [[The Cure]]. Singer [[Katie Melua]] recorded a cover version of the song for the soundtrack of the film. Melua's version is played over the opening titles, and has lines such as "she said" changed to "he said" to maintain a heterosexual narrative. The original version by The Cure, as well as the remainder of Melua's version, are played over the closing credits. The orchestral score was written by [[Rolfe Kent]], and orchestrated by [[Tony Blondal]]. ==Soundtrack== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! Track No. !! Title !! revision.text:
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Learn from Dazhai in agriculture.jpg|right|300px|thumb|Propaganda poster. The text says, "''Let the whole Party mobilize its membership to practice agriculture on a large scale; let them fight to popularize Dazhai County (''sic'')!''"]] --> The "'''Learn from Dazhai in agriculture'''" Campaign ({{zh|c={{linktext|农业|学|大寨}}|p=nóngyè xué Dàzhài}}, or in [[Wade-Giles]] [[Romanization]] '''Tachai''') was a campaign organized by [[Mao Zedong]] in 1963. The campaign encouraged peasants from all over China to follow from the example of the farmers of [[Dazhai]] village, [[Shanxi]], by practicing self-sacrifice and upright political activity.
It grew in importance after the introduction of the [[Cultural Revolution]], but [[Chen Yonggui]] and its other proponents were eventually eased out of power by [[Deng Xiaoping]] following the removal of the [[Gang of Four]].
==History==
Slogans associated with Dazhai included: "Move the mountains to make farm fields," "Change the sky and alter the land," "Work bitterly, diligently, and with extra energy, and build our village into a Dazhai-like one in three years."
During the years until the downfall of the [[Gang of Four]] in 1976, particularly the [[Cultural Revolution]], farmers from all over the country were organized to visit Dazhai, and well-trained tour guides took posts at important scenes to explain to visitors how the villagers in Daizhai made such achievements with their own hands. One of such scenes was the top of the [[Tiger Head Mountain]] where visitors could have a panoramic view of the farm fields, the major irrigation projects as well as the residential area of the villagers. Perhaps hundreds of millions of farmers visited the place during the period and the expenses on their trips were paid{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} by the government.
At this time, farmers throughout China were expected to show their political zeal in following [[Mao Zedong]]'s directive "Learn from Dazhai in agriculture" ("农业|学大寨"). They not only worked during the day, but at night as well, not only in the warm season, but in the depth of winter—a dramatic deviation from their age-old practice. In many places, the farmers literally—and blindly—moved hills (sometimes proclaimed as "mountains"), built reservoirs, tunnels, canals, and so on. As mental motivation, loud speakers were installed at work sites to broadcast music and songs and films were shown at night on the scene while the farmers took a break.
Meanwhile, a number of leaders of the village made dramatic advances in their political careers. [[Chen Yonggui]], the patriarchal leader of the village, was put to the position of [[vice premier]] of the central government despite the fact that he was only semiliterate. ([[Zhou Enlai]] was the [[premier]] of the time.) [[Guo Fenglian]], the Dazhai [[party secretary]], was a favorite of [[Jiang Qing]] (the wife of [[Mao Zedong]]), and played a significant part in the Chinese political scene.
This campaign was as much political as it was agricultural, and it came to an abrupt end upon Mao's death in 1976.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} After the victory of [[Deng Xiaoping]] over [[Hua Guofeng]], [[Chen Yonggui]], and others following the removal of the [[Gang of Four]] from power, his [[economic reform in the People's Republic of China|economic reforms]] has caused Dazhai to become a figure of ridicule, since it was so closely linked to Maoist communal agriculture and socialist propaganda.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/asia/magazine/99/0927/dazhai.html TIMEasia.com | Visions of China: Dazhai | 9/27/99<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.sacu.org/learntachai.html Learn from Dazhai<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Today, Dazhai is a regional tourist attraction.
==See also== {{div col}} * [[Learn from Daqing in industry]] * [[Agriculture in China]] * [[History of agriculture in the People's Republic of China]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100304163532/http://www.acjournal.org/holdings/vol5/iss1/articles/lu.htm Lu, "Dazhai: Imagistic Rhetoric as a Cultural Instrument Xin-An Lu"] * [http://chineseposters.net/themes/dazhai.php Posters about Dazhai] * [http://chineseposters.net/posters/e12-604.php Poster showing the slogan]

revision.text:
{{for|the interactive performance project with the same name|Restless Natives (performance)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Use British English|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Restless Natives | image = Restless_natives_poster.jpg | caption = Film Poster | starring = [[Vincent Friell]]
Joe Mullaney
| writer = Ninian Dunnett | director = [[Michael Hoffman (American director)|Michael Hoffman]] | producer = [[Rick Stevenson]]
[[Andy Paterson]]
Mark Bentley | music = [[Stuart Adamson]] | cinematography = [[Oliver Stapleton]] | studio = [[EMI Films]] | distributor = [[Thorn EMI Screen Entertainment]]
[[Orion Classics]] | released = {{film date|df=y|1985|6||UK|1986|9|12|USA}} | runtime = 90 minutes | country = Scotland | language = English | budget = £1.2 millionAlexander Walker, ''Icons in the Fire: The Rise and Fall of Practically Everyone in the British Film Industry 1984-2000'', Orion Books, 2005 p35 | gross = £300,000 }} '''''Restless Natives''''' is a 1985 [[Scotland|Scottish]] cinema adventure comedy, directed by [[Michael Hoffman (American director)|Michael Hoffman]]. ==Plot== The story follows the adventures of two Scottish youths from the [[Wester Hailes]] district of [[Edinburgh]], played by [[Vincent Friell]] and [[Joe Mullaney (actor)|Joe Mullaney]], who, in rebellion to their drab lives in urban Scotland in the mid-1980's become modern [[highwayman|highwaymen]]. Donning masks of a clown and a wolf-man and riding a [[Honda CG125]] motorbike, for a joke they waylay and hold up with a toy gun tourist coaches in the [[Scottish Highlands|Highlands]], in the process becoming a tourist attraction themselves. Having inadvertently acquired substantial amounts of money, they proceed to become modern [[Robin Hood|Robin Hoods]], doling it out to the poor of their city by scattering it on bike rides through its streets, attracting national media attention and pursuit by the police.'Our Top 10 Most Scottish Films, #7 Restless Natives,' 'The Scots Magazine', 4 March 2015. https://www.scotsmagazine.com/articles//top-10-scottish-films-number-7/'Comical strivings in Restless Natives', 'The New York Times;, 12 September 1986. https://www.nytimes.com/1986/09/12/movies/film-comical-strivings-in-restless-natives.html ==Themes== 'Restless Natives' - as suggested by its title - has underlying themes beyond its superficial presentation as a light social comedy film. It was produced at a time of high unemployment in the [[United Kingdom]], with Scotland being particularly affected by post-industrial economic blight, and being governed from London by an Anglocentric radical [[Thatcherism|political order]] that the Scottish people had collectively electorally rejected in the recent [[1983 United Kingdom general election]]. The main storyline's premise reflected the frustration of mid-1980's Scottish working class youth, with limited life chances and economic prospects at home, breaking free of their constraint in the dispiriting confines of a grim cityscape of mid-20th Century [[Brutalist]] urban architecture, using the freedom facilitated by a motorcycle (in a tacit reference to a recent admonition from a [[Norman Tebbit|British Government Minister]] to the millions of unemployed in the country to "get on their bikes" to find elusive jobs);Restless Natives' trailer, published on Youtube, 26 August 2014. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tM9rUC18JFs to escape into revitalizing open vistas of the landscape of the Scottish Highlands. The production was a part of a group of small-budget cinematic productions, along with titles such as [[Gregory's Girl]] (1981), [[Local Hero]] (1983), that brought stories of contemporary life in Scotland to a global cinema audience. The film was a commercial success on release in Scotland and acquired cult status, being regarded as a homemade expression of local Scottish cultural pride, becoming a minor media source of insurgent Scottish cultural identity, subliminally juxtaposed to [[Britishness]], and feeding into the developing proto-[[Scottish Nationalist]] movement in the arts, with its soaring distinctive soundtrack from the band [[Big Country (band)|Big Country]], whose music dealt with the same themes.'Cult Movie Column - Restless Natives', 'The Skinny' magazine, 15 July 2006. https://www.theskinny.co.uk/film/opinion/cult-movie-column-restless-natives ==Music score== The soundtrack features music from the band [[Big Country]]. This music was not released on an album but was combined into two lengthy tracks, each featuring various pieces of music and clips of actors from the film's audio, which appeared on limited edition formats of two Big Country 12" singles. It was released on CD for the first time on the 1998 Big Country collection 'Restless Natives & Rarities', where it is presented as a single 35-minute track. ==Production== The screenplay won a film script writing competition held by [[Lloyds Bank]] before it was optioned for production.'Cult Movie Column - Restless Natives', 'The Skinny' magazine, 15 July 2006. https://www.theskinny.co.uk/film/opinion/cult-movie-column-restless-natives'On the side of the Angels', Malcolm, Derek. The Guardian 27 June 1985. ==Reception== The film performed well at the box office in Scotland, but commercially failed in other markets. ==See also== * [[Restless Nation]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0089904}} * [http://dearscotland.com/2010/08/13/you-have-been-watching-restless-natives/ Dear Scotland: You have been watching... Restless Natives (review)] * [http://www.theskinny.co.uk/film/opinion/cult-movie-column-restless-natives The Skinny: Cult Movie Column - Restless Natives] {{Michael Hoffman}} [[Category:1985 films]] [[Category:1980s comedy films]] [[Category:British comedy films]] [[Category:Scottish films]] [[Category:Films set in Scotland]] [[Category:Entertainment in Scotland]] [[Category:Arts in Scotland]] [[Category:1985 in Scotland]] [[Category:Scottish comedy]] [[Category:Films directed by Michael Hoffman]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:Films shot in Edinburgh]] [[Category:British road movies]]

revision.text:
{{for|the Caravaggio painting in Valletta of the same title|Saint Jerome Writing (Caravaggio, Valletta)}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=File:Saint Jerome Writing-Caravaggio (1605-6).jpg | title=Saint Jerome | artist=Caravaggio | year=c. 1605–1606 | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=112 | width_metric=157 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=Galleria Borghese }} '''''Saint Jerome Writing''''', also called '''''Saint Jerome in His Study''''' or simply '''''Saint Jerome''''', is an [[oil painting]] by [[Italians|Italian]] painter [[Caravaggio]]. Generally dated to 1605-1606, the painting is located in the [[Galleria Borghese]] in [[Rome]].
==Composition== The painting depicts [[Jerome|Saint Jerome]], a [[Doctor of the Church]] in [[Roman Catholicism]] and a popular subject for painting, even for Caravaggio, who produced other paintings of Jerome [[Saint Jerome in Meditation (Caravaggio)|in Meditation]] and [[Saint Jerome Writing (Valletta)|engaged in writing]]. In this image, Jerome is reading intently, an outstretched arm resting with quill. It has been suggested that Jerome is depicted in the act of translating the ''Vulgate''.<ref name="Bussagli2009">{{cite book|last=Bussagli|first=Marco|title=Italian Art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=80DpE2Y-xlAC&pg=PA346|accessdate=28 June 2010|date=April 2009|publisher=Giunti Editore Firenze Italy|isbn=978-88-09-03726-7|page=346}}</ref>
==History== The painting is generally dated to 1605-1606, largely on the statements of 17th-century art historical biographer [[Gian Pietro Bellori]], though [[Denis Mahon]] suggests 1602-1604.<ref name="GilbertCaravaggio1995">{{cite book|last=Gilbert|first=Creighton|title=Caravaggio and His Two Cardinals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7WSH4BabKuUC&pg=PA107|accessdate=28 June 2010|year=1995|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=978-0-271-01312-1|pages=107–}}</ref><ref name="Hibbard1985">{{cite book|last=Hibbard|first=Howard|title=Caravaggio|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wAvz9G4DhdkC&pg=PA320|accessdate=28 June 2010|date=5 March 1985|publisher=Westview Press|isbn=978-0-06-430128-2|page=320}}</ref><ref name="MorenoStefani2000">{{cite book|last1=Moreno|first1=Paolo|author2=Chiara Stefani|title=The Borghese Gallery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ce2Fg7FIvFgC&pg=PA192|accessdate=28 June 2010|year=2000|publisher=Touring Editore|isbn=978-88-365-1946-0|page=192}}</ref> According to Bellori, Caravaggio produced the piece at the behest of [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|Cardinal]] [[Scipione Borghese]],<ref name="BelloriWohl2005">{{cite book|last1=Bellori|first1=Giovanni Pietro|authorlink1=Giovanni Pietro Bellori|translator=Hellmut Wohl|title=The lives of the modern painters, sculptors and architects|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lm9gs8mXwOUC&pg=PA188|accessdate=28 June 2010|year=2005|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-78187-9|page=188}}</ref> who became a cardinal in 1605, but it is possible that Borghese acquired it later as it is not mentioned in a 1613 poem by [[Scipione Francucci]] that described the [[Borghese Collection|Borghese Caravaggio collection]].<ref name="GilbertCaravaggio1995"/> Whether or not the dating is accurate, the work is believed to have originated from Caravaggio's late Roman period,<ref name="CaravaggioPomella2005">{{cite book|last=Pomella|first=Andrea|title=Caravaggio: An Artist through Images|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JDH4lOa8qRgC&pg=PA105|accessdate=28 June 2010|year=2005|publisher=ATS Italia Editrice|isbn=978-88-88536-62-0|page=105}}</ref> which ended with the painter's exile to [[Malta]] in 1606.<ref>Hibbard (1985), p. 206.</ref>
That ''Saint Jerome Writing'' is the work of Caravaggio is sometimes brought into question, as it was attributed to [[Jusepe de Ribera|Ribera]] in the Borghese inventories from 1700 until 1893.<ref name="Hibbard1985"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Caravaggio}}

page.title: Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | title = Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird | image_file = Frida_Kahlo_(self_portrait).jpg | other_language_1= Spanish | other_title_1 = Autorretrato con Collar de Espinas | artist = [[Frida Kahlo]] | year = 1940 | medium = [[Oil on canvas]] | height_metric = 61.25 | width_metric = 47 | height_imperial = 24.11 | width_imperial = 18.5 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Austin]] | museum = [[Harry Ransom Center]], [[University of Texas at Austin]] }}
'''''Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird''''' (''Autorretrato con Collar de Espinas'') is a 1940 painting by Mexican painter [[Frida Kahlo]].
Kahlo painted the self-portrait after her divorce from [[Diego Rivera]] and the end of her affair with photographer [[Nickolas Muray]]. Muray bought the portrait shortly after it was painted, and it is currently part of the Nickolas Muray collection at the Harry Ransom Center at the [[University of Texas at Austin]].<ref>Ditrich, "Self-portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird".</ref>
==Background== [[Frida Kahlo]] was a Mexican painter active between 1925 and 1954. She began painting while bedridden due to a bus accident that left her seriously disabled. Most of her work consists of self-portraits, which deal directly with her struggle with medical issues, infertility, and her troubled marriage to Rivera. Painting self-portraits was therapeutic, allowing Kahlo to create a separate Frida on which to project her anguish and pain.<ref name="Herrera">Herrera, “Kahlo, Frida".</ref> Scholars have interpreted her self portraits as a way for Kahlo to reclaim her body from medical issues and gender conformity. In particular, scholars have interpreted her self-portraits in the context of the tradition of male European artists using the female body as the subject of their paintings and an object of desire.<ref>Udall, “Frida Kahlo’s Mexican Body,” 13.</ref> Kahlo, using her own image, reclaims this use from the patriarchal tradition. The autobiographical details of her life found in these works as well as her characteristic brows, elaborate hair, and vibrant Mexican clothing has made her a popular figure in Mexico and the United States.
Kahlo was a big supporter of the [[Mexican Revolution]], so much so that she attempted to change her birth date to correspond with the beginning of the Revolution in 1910.<ref name="Herrera"/> At the onset of this movement, a so-called “cult of Mexican femininity” gained popularity, which Jolie Olcott describes as “selflessness, martyrdom, self-sacrifice, an erasure of self and the negation of one’s outward existence.”<ref>Pankl and Blake, “Made in Her Image,” 5.</ref> In rejection of this limited conception of femininity, Kahlo fashioned herself as a Mexican counterpart to the [[flapper]]s of the United States and Europe in the 1920s. Later, inspired by Rivera’s concept of [[Mexicanidad]], a passionate identification with Mexican pre-Hispanic indigenous roots, she donned the identity of the [[Tehuana]] woman.<ref name="Herrera"/> The Tehuana had a great deal of equality with their male [[Zapotec peoples|Zapotec]] counterparts and represented strength, sensuality, and exoticism.<ref name="PanklBlake8">Pankl and Blake, “Made in Her Image,” 8.</ref>
==Visual analysis== This rather small painting (approximately 24” x 18”), shows Kahlo in a frontal position and directly confronting the viewer’s gaze from the canvas. Her bold eyebrows hold the emphasis on her face, as a thorn necklace strangles her throat, trailing down her chest like the roots of a tree. A small black hummingbird with its wings outstretched hangs like a pendant from her throat. She is surrounded by insects and animals, setting the scene of a lush, but suffocatingly dense jungle. A monkey sits behind her right shoulder, its eyes focused on its hands, tugging at the thorn necklace, causing Kahlo to bleed. Above her head, two dragonflies float in mid-air, above two butterfly clips nesting in the elaborate hairstyle that crowns her head. A black panther with striking ice blue eyes peers over her left shoulder watching.
==Symbolism== Kahlo’s identification with indigenous Mexican culture greatly affected her painting aesthetic. By using powerful iconography from indigenous Mexican culture, Kahlo situates herself in a tradition of rebellion against colonial forces and male rule.<ref name="PanklBlake8"/> The dead hummingbird which hangs around her neck is considered a good luck charm for falling in love in Mexican folklore.<ref name="FuentesKahlo78"/> An alternate interpretation is that the hummingbird pendant is a symbol of [[Huitzilopochtli]], the [[Aztec]] god of war.<ref>Baddeley, “Her Dress Hangs Here,” 13.</ref> Meanwhile, the black panther is symbolic of bad luck and death and the monkey is a symbol of evil.<ref name="FuentesKahlo78">Fuentes and Kahlo, The Diary of Frida Kahlo,” 78.</ref> The natural landscape, which normally symbolizes fertility, contrasts with the deathly imagery in the foreground. Rivera gave Kahlo a [[spider monkey]] as a gift, thus suggesting that it could be a symbol of Rivera, especially since he inflicts pain upon Kahlo by tugging the thorn necklace hard enough to make her bleed.<ref name="FuentesKahlo78"/> Alternately, the thorn necklace could allude to Christ’s crown of thorns, thus likening herself to a Christian martyr, and representing the pain and anguish she felt after her failed romantic relationships. In line with this interpretation, the butterflies and dragonflies could symbolize her resurrection.<ref name="PanklBlake8"/>
== Exhibition history ==
The University of Texas at Austin acquired the painting in 1966. Since 1990, it has appeared in several exhibitions internationally:
* "Frida Kahlo," [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]], February 20, 2008 - May 18, 2008<ref>{{cite web|title=Frida Kahlo.|url=http://www.philamuseum.org/exhibitions/278.html|website=Philadelphia Museum of Art|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> * Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas at Austin, May 5, 2009 - March 21, 2010 * "In Wonderland: The Surrealist Activities of Women Artists in Mexico and the United States," [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]], January 29, 2012 – May 6, 2012;<ref>{{cite web|title=In Wonderland: The Surrealist Adventures of Women Artists in Mexico and the United States.|url=http://www.lacma.org/art/exhibition/wonderland-surrealist-adventures-women-artists-mexico-and-united-states|website=Los Angeles County Museum of Art|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> [[Musée national des beaux-arts du Québec]], [[Quebec City]], June 7, 2012 - September 3, 2012; [[Museo de Arte Moderno]], [[Mexico City]], September 27, 2012 - Jan. 13, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frida Kahlo's "Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird" at Ransom Center in Austin|url=http://artdaily.com/news/48872/Frida-Kahlo-s--Self-Portrait-with-Thorn-Necklace-and-Hummingbird--at-Ransom-Center-in-Austin#.VPy07_nF82c|website=Art Daily.|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> * "Frida Kahlo," Scuderie del Quirinale, [[Rome]], March 20, 2014 - August 31, 2014<ref>{{cite web|title=Frida Kahlo: List of Works|url=http://english.scuderiequirinale.it/categorie/list-of-works-frida-kahlo|website=Scuderie del Quirinale|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> * Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas at Austin, September 5, 2014 - April 26, 2015<ref>{{cite web|title=Frida Kahlo's Self-portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird|url=http://www.hrc.utexas.edu/exhibitions/2014/kahlo/|website=Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas at Austin|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> * "Frida: Art, Garden, Life," [[New York Botanical Garden]], May 16, 2015 - November 1, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=About the Show: Frida Kahlo: Art, Garden, Life|url=http://www.nybg.org/frida/|website=New York Botanical Garden|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
== References == *Baddeley, Oriana. "'Her Dress Hangs Here: De-Frocking the Kahlo Cult." ''Oxford Art Journal'' 14, no. 1 (1991): 10-17. *Dietrich, Alicia. "[http://blog.hrc.utexas.edu/2013/02/14/frida-kahlos-self-portrait-with-thorn-necklace-and-hummingbird-back-on-display-today/ Frida Kahlo's "Self-portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird" back on display today]." Cultural Compass. February 14, 2013. Accessed March 21, 2017. *Fuentes, Carlos and Frida Kahlo. ''The Diary of Frida Kahlo: An Intimate Self-Portrait''. New York: Bloomsbury, 1995. *Hayden Herrera. "[http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T045455 Kahlo, Frida]." Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online. Oxford University Press, accessed March 21, 2017. *Pankl, Lis and Kevin Blake. "Made in Her Image: Frida Kahlo as Material Culture." ''Material Culture'' 44, no. 2 (2012): 1-20. *Udall, Sharyn R. "Frida Kahlo's Mexican Body: History, Identity, and Artistic Aspiration." ''Woman's Art Journal'' 24, no. 2 (2003): 10-14.
{{Frida Kahlo}}
{{authority control}}
[[Category:1940 paintings]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Cats in art]] [[Category:Insects in art]] [[Category:Monkeys in art]] [[Category:Paintings by Frida Kahlo]] [[Category:Paintings in Texas]] [[Category:Self-portraits]]

{{Infobox recurring event | name = | logo = | image = | imagesize = 300px | caption = | genre = Fashion show, exhibitions and competitions | date = | frequency = Semi-annually | location = [[Novi Sad]], Serbia | first = | prev = <!-- [[previous event]] --> | next = <!-- [[next event]] --> | participants = Serbian and international designers, industry experts | attendance = 30,000/year | area = | budget = | patron = | organised = | founder_name = Svetlana Horvat | member = | website = http://www.serbiafashionweek.com | footnotes = }} '''Serbia Fashion Week''' is a fashion show held twice a year in [[Novi Sad]], [[Serbia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishnews.com/lifestyle/2017/09/02/news/danube-city-novi-sad-is-the-jewel-in-serbia-s-crown-1123565/|title=Danube city Novi Sad is the jewel in Serbia's crown|website=The Irish News}}</ref> Occurring in April and November, the event attracts local and international fashion designers, such as [[Thierry Mugler]] and [[Anna Fendi]]. In addition to runway shows, seminars and exhibits, the "Fashion Talent Design Competition" helps promote young Serbian designers by showcasing their collections. The seven day festival also highlights the works of applied artists, musicians, interior decorators, multimedia experts and architects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://novisad.travel/en/events/serbia-fashion-week-2/|title=Serbia Fashion Week - TONS|publisher=}}</ref>
The fashion show portion is often held at the Congress Centre Master of the Novi Sad Fair, a multi-functional venue situated near the center of the city. Other locations are used as well, for the opening shows, concerts, and art exhibits. Each year, about 30,000 visitors attend with approximately 60 fashion designers, from 20 different countries, presenting their collections.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20171231/fashion-beauty/Maltese-designer-at-Serbia-Fashion-Week.666847|title=Maltese designer at Serbia Fashion Week|first=Allied Newspapers|last=Ltd|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="belgrade-beat.com">{{cite web|url=https://belgrade-beat.com/magazine/2017/11/serbian-fashion-week-autumnwinter-201718|title=Serbian Fashion Week Autumn/Winter 2017/18 - Belgrade Beat|website=belgrade-beat.com}}</ref><ref name="blic.rs">{{cite web|url=https://zena.blic.rs/moda/spektakularno-zatvaranje-novembarskog-serbia-fashion-weeka-zabelezeno-vise-od-35000/nm45zt6|title=Spektakularno zatvaranje novembarskog Serbia Fashion Weeka: Zabeleženo više od 35.000 posetilaca!|publisher=}}</ref>
==About== Partially sponsored by the municipal government, Serbia Fashion Week was founded in 2013 by current head Svetlana Horvat. Having worked as a womenswear designer, she is also the current president of the National Serbian Chamber of Fashion.<ref name="topsrbija.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.topsrbija.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=6533:svetlana-horvat-najavila-spektakularnu-nacionalnu-nedelju-mode-&catid=320:manastiri&Itemid=563|title=Svetlana Horvat najavila spektakularnu Nacionalnu nedelju mode|website=www.topsrbija.com}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://rtv.rs/sr_ci/vojvodina/novi-sad/serbia-fashion-week-od-24.-do-29.-aprila-na-pet-lokacija-u-ns_911596.html|title="Serbia fashion week" од 24. до 29. априла на пет локација у НС|first=Јавна медијска установа ЈМУ Радио-телевизија|last=Војводине|website=ЈМУ Радио-телевизија Војводине}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novisad.rs/otvara-e-prvog-serbia-fashion-week|title=ОТВАРАЊЕ ПРВОГ „SERBIA FASHION WEEK“ - Novi Sad|website=www.novisad.rs}}</ref> On October 31, 2013, Horvat made the fashion week official by signing the "Protocol on Cooperation" with the national [[European Fashion Council|Fashion Councils]] of eight other European countries.<ref name="europaregina.eu">{{cite web|url=http://europaregina.eu/fashion-week/serbia-fashion-week/|title=Serbia Fashion Week - World Fashion Calendar, International Fashion Weeks|website=europaregina.eu}}</ref><ref name="novisad.rs">{{cite web|url=http://www.novisad.rs/otvara-e-prvog-serbia-fashion-week-u-novom-sadu|title=ОТВАРАЊЕ ПРВОГ „SERBIA FASHION WEEK“ У НОВОМ САДУ - Novi Sad|website=www.novisad.rs}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://europaregina.eu/organizations/european-fashion-council/european-fashion-council-03272012.htm|title=Serbia is the 19th member state of the European Fashion Council|publisher=}}</ref>
The event's main objective is to present Serbian talent alongside designers from established European fashion capitals.<ref name="europaregina.eu"/> Other goals include encouraging the local textile and manufacturing industries, as well as promoting tourism in the area.<ref name="europaregina.eu"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://europaregina.eu/fashion-weeks/fashion-weeks-europe/serbia-fashion-week|title=Serbia Fashion Week - Serbia, Europe|publisher=}}</ref>
==Highlights== === SFW 2013 === The very first Serbia Fashion Week took place from October 31st to November 2nd, 2013. It featured designers from Serbia, the Netherlands, Hungary, Bulgaria, among others.<ref name="novisad.rs"/><ref name="europaregina.eu"/> French designer Eymeric François opened the show and Marcellous L. Jones, owner of "Fashion Insider TV", acted as adviser for the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lepotaizdravlje.rs/lifestyle/inspirisemo-vas/u-novom-sadu-otvoren-serbia-fashion-week/|title=U Novom Sadu otvoren Serbia Fashion Week|website=lepotaizdravlje.rs}}</ref><ref name="svet.rs">{{cite web|url=http://www.svet.rs/vesti/estrada/uskoro-prvi-serbia-fashion-week|title=Uskoro prvi Serbia Fashion Week|publisher=}}</ref> Two main themes defined the festival, High Fashion and Urban Fashion, with runway shows held at locations such as the [[Assembly of Vojvodina]].<ref name="novisad.rs"/> A conference on fashion branding also took place at the assembly building.<ref name="belgrade-beat.com"/> About 2,500 visitors attended the first festival in 2013.<ref name="belgrade-beat.com"/> As part of the "Designer Exchange" program, local talent Biljana Tipsarević was later able to represent Serbia at [[Malta]] Fashion Week.<ref name="svet.rs"/> === SFW 2014 === The special guest of honour, at the October 2014 edition, was [[Maastricht]] mayor, [[Onno Hoes]], who participated in the Fashion Educational Conference Series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraf.rs/zivot-i-stil/1268532-za-serbia-fashion-week-trazi-se-karta-vise-foto|title=Za Serbia Fashion Week traži se karta više! (FOTO)|website=www.telegraf.rs}}</ref><ref name="thefashioninsider.com">http://thefashioninsider.com/2014/11/21/serbia-fashion-week-posts-spectacular-growth/</ref> He spoke about the role of city governments in helping fashion events evolve.<ref name="thefashioninsider.com"/> The opening ceremony took place at the [[Eđšeg]] chateau. Local designers, who presented their collections, included [[Verica Rakocević]], Marija Šabić, [[Zvonko Marković]], [[Bata Spasojević]], and Milena Radović.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hellomagazin.rs/moda/modne-vesti/serbia-fashion-week-nedelja-kreativnosti-u-novom-sadu/|title=Serbia Fashion Week: Nedelja kreativnosti u Novom Sadu|publisher=}}</ref> That same year, Dutch designers began regularly showing their clothing lines, after a cooperation agreement between Serbia Fashion Week and FashionClash festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fashionclash.nl/fashionclash-serbia-fashion-week/|title=FASHIONCLASH & Serbia Fashion Week|website=FASHIONCLASH}}</ref> Art exhibits included the works of French photographer [[Thomas Devaux]] and Serbian sculptor Vladimir Labat Rovnjev.<ref name="thefashioninsider.com"/> The festival saw 14,000 visitors in 2014.<ref name="thefashioninsider.com"/> === SFW 2015 === Inspired by [[David Bowie]], one runway show in April 2015 was called "Heros" and spotlighted about 20 Serbian designers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://zena.blic.rs/moda/revijom-heroji-otvoren-serbia-fashion-week/6wj34fh|title=Revijom "Heroji" otvoren Serbia Fashion Week|publisher=}}</ref> [[Vogue Italia|Italian Vogue]] covered the event's spring edition, mentioning local talents Zorana Milicic and Marija Stankovic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.it/en/talents/news/2015/05/serbia-fashion-week?refresh_ce=|title=Serbia Fashion Week - Vogue.it|publisher=}}</ref> French designer Eymeric François also participated, presenting his collection on the second day.<ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=http://www.rtv.rs/sr_lat/zivot/zenski-kutak/vise-od-50-dizajnera-iz-srbije-i-evrope-na-nacionalnoj-nedelji-mode_578417.html|title=Više od 50 dizajnera iz Srbije i Evrope na nacionalnoj nedelji mode|first=Javna medijska ustanova JMU Radio-televizija|last=Vojvodine|website=JMU Radio-televizija Vojvodine}}</ref> A seminar on "Digital Marketing in the Fashion Industry" took place as well.<ref name="auto2"/> At the November show, the awards ceremony was held at the [[Petrovaradin Fortress]], with presentations made by fashion critic Marcellous L. Jones and Donald Potard, former managing director of the [[Jean Paul Gautier]] fashion house.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hellomagazin.rs/moda/modne-vesti/serbia-fashion-week-svecano-dodeljene-modne-nagrade/|title=Serbia Fashion Week: Svečano dodeljene modne nagrade|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="belgrade-beat.com"/> === SFW 2016 === In 2016, Novi Sad's Popovic sisters, Mila and Tijana, focused on eco-design, by presenting garments made of recycled materials.<ref name="mojnovisad.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.mojnovisad.com/vesti/serbia-fashion-week-kratki-vodic-kroz-novosadsku-nedelju-mode-id8920.html|title=Serbia Fashion Week: Kratki vodič kroz novosadsku Nedelju mode|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mojnovisad.com/vesti/tijana-i-mila-popovic-novosadjanke-cije-modele-nosi-i-billy-idol-id7559.html|title=[GRADSKE FACE] Tijana i Mila Popović: Novosađanke čije modele nosi i Billy Idol|publisher=}}</ref> International designers at the show included German Isabell De Hellerin and Slovenian Nika Ravnik, as well as Lesia Semi from the Ukraine.<ref name="mojnovisad.com"/> Prizes were handed out at the French embassy in [[Belgrade]], with jury members consisting of fashion expert Donald Potard and designer [[Anna Fendi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraf.rs/zivot-i-stil/2458910-zavrsnica-serbia-fashion-weeka-krunisana-glamuroznom-dodelom-nagrada-serbia-fashion-awards-foto|title=Završnica SERBIA FASHION WEEKA krunisana glamuroznom dodelom nagrada - SERBIA FASHION AWARDS! (FOTO)|website=www.telegraf.rs}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.it/en/vogue-talents/news/2016/11/22/serbia-fashion-week-spring-summer-2017/|title=Serbia Fashion Week 2016|date=22 November 2016|publisher=}}</ref> [[Fendi]] also visited Novi Sad to promote her new selection of wines from her AFV label.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraf.rs/zivot-i-stil/2398276-anna-fendi-dolazi-na-serbia-fashion-week|title=ANNA FENDI dolazi na Serbia Fashion Week!|website=www.telegraf.rs}}</ref> Additionally, the Novi Sad event was showcased at [[New York Fashion Week]], featuring the collections of local designers [[Bata Spasojević]] and Marina Ilić.<ref name="topsrbija.com"/><ref>https://newyorkstyleguide.com/marinia-by-marina-ilic-show-new-york-fashion-week-art-hearts-fashion/</ref> An exchange of designers also took place between D.C. Fashion Week and Serbia Fashion Week.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.afro.com/ean-williams-rips-the-runway-as-director-of-d-c-fashion-week/|title=Ean Williams Rips the Runway as Director of D.C. Fashion Week - Afro|website=www.afro.com}}</ref>
=== SFW 2017 === In 2017, designer Suzana Perić had a runway show noted for its boho style and local pop singer [[Ana Stanić]] performed at the festival.<ref name="blic.rs"/> Italian fashion was highlighted, as well as showcasing designers from Croatia, Spain, Romania and Belarus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://it.fashionnetwork.com/news/La-moda-Made-in-Italy-protagonista-alla-Serbia-Fashion-Week,896693.html#.WzZMA2BKjcc|title=La moda Made in Italy protagonista alla Serbia Fashion Week|first=|last=FashionNetwork.com|publisher=}}</ref> A new segment at the event, featuring films about fashion, was inaugurated, with cinematic works from various film festivals being shown.<ref name="blic.rs1">{{cite web|url=https://zena.blic.rs/moda/umetnost-avangarda-i-biznis-serbia-fashion-week-povezao-dizajnere-sa-cetiri/md016wg|title=Umetnost, avangarda i biznis: Serbia Fashion Week povezao dizajnere sa četiri kontinenta|publisher=}}</ref> Additionally, a number of foreign fashion press were in attendance, including World of Fashion (Italy), Runway Manhattan (USA), Fashion Insider (USA), and El Sharkiah Magazine (Saudi Arabia).<ref name="blic.rs1"/> The executive director of Malta Fashion Week, Adrian Mizzi, gave out awards at the closing ceremonies, held at the Italian embassy in [[Belgrade]]. He was accompanied by [[Gucci]] Fashion House heiress, Patricia Gucci, who also signed copies of her new book, which was published in the Serbian language and examines her family’s clothing empire.<ref name="auto"/><ref name="belgrade-beat.com"/> <ref name="blic.rs"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtv.rs/sr_ci/vojvodina/novi-sad/serbia-fashion-week-od-20.-do-27.-novembra_870050.html|title=''Serbia fashion week'' од 20. до 27. новембра - ЈМУ Радио-телевизија Војводине|first=Јавна медијска установа ЈМУ Радио-телевизија|last=Војводине|website=ЈМУ Радио-телевизија Војводине}}</ref> By 2017, the number of visitors to Serbia Fashion Week had jumped to 30,000.<ref name="belgrade-beat.com"/>
=== SFW 2018 === In April 2018, fashion designer [[Thierry Mugler]] was the special guest and featured designer, celebrating the 10th jubilee edition of the festival.<ref name="auto1"/><ref name="lepotaizdravlje.rs">{{cite web|url=http://www.lepotaizdravlje.rs/lifestyle/promo/serbia-fashion-week-zatvoren-nevidenim-modnim-souom/|title=Serbia Fashion Week zatvoren neviđenim modnim šouom|website=lepotaizdravlje.rs}}</ref> The opening ceremony took place on a giant runway in [[Danube Park]] and the awards ceremony was held at the [[Serbian National Theater]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/lifestyle.305.html:724114-Serbia-Fashion-Week-otvoren-spektaklom-pod-vedrim-nebom-FOTO|title=Serbia Fashion Week otvoren spektaklom pod vedrim nebom (FOTO)|website=www.novosti.rs}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtv.rs/sr_ci/vojvodina/novi-sad/mladost-glamur-i-novi-trendovi-na-serbia-fashion-week-u-(video)_913448.html|title=Младост, гламур и нови трендови на Serbia Fashion Week-у (ВИДЕО)|first=Јавна медијска установа ЈМУ Радио-телевизија|last=Војводине|website=ЈМУ Радио-телевизија Војводине}}</ref><ref name="serbiafashionweek.com">{{cite web|url=http://serbiafashionweek.com/en/2018/04/30/sfw-april-2018-tomorrow/|title=SERBIA FASHION WEEK APRIL 2018 STARTS TOMORROW|date=30 April 2018|publisher=}}</ref> Designer [[Zvonko Marković]] celebrated 20 years in the fashion industry by presenting a special collection.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://zena.blic.rs/moda/modna-bajka-zvonka-markovica-na-serbia-fashion-weeku/g9vbxbj|title=Modna bajka Zvonka Markovića na Serbia Fashion Weeku|publisher=}}</ref> Local pop singer [[Tijana Bogićević]] performed her Eurovision entry "In Too Deep" while wearing a 60 meter long dress.<ref name="lepotaizdravlje.rs"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2017/04/25/serbia-tijana-bogicevic-opens-serbia-fashion-week/|title=Serbia: Tijana Bogićević Opens Serbia Fashion Week - Eurovoix|date=25 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref> Sales advisor Barbara Locatelli and fashion editor Myra Postolache led some of the educational seminars on business and public relations.<ref name="serbiafashionweek.com"/> Representatives from [[Vancouver Fashion Week]] and Holland's Fashionclash show were also in attendance.
==See also== * [[Belgrade Fashion Week]] * [[Belgrade Design Week]] * [[The Applied Artists and Designers Association of Serbia]]

page.title: Symphony in D major, Op. 3, No. 2 (Stamitz)

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = The 5th Wave | image = 5th-Wave poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[J Blakeson]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Graham King]] * [[Tobey Maguire]] * Lynn Harris * Matthew Plouffe }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * [[Susannah Grant]] * [[Akiva Goldsman]] * [[Jeff Pinkner]] }} | based on = {{Based on|''[[The 5th Wave (novel)|The 5th Wave]]''|[[Rick Yancey]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist|<!--- Per closing credits ---> * [[Chloë Grace Moretz]] * [[Nick Robinson (American actor)|Nick Robinson]] * [[Ron Livingston]] * [[Maggie Siff]] * [[Alex Roe]] * [[Maria Bello]] * [[Maika Monroe]] * [[Zackary Arthur]] * [[Liev Schreiber]] }} | music = [[Henry Jackman]] | cinematography = [[Enrique Chediak]] | editing = [[Paul Rubell]] | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[Columbia Pictures]]<ref name=thr>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/5th-wave-film-review-855621|title='The 5th Wave': Film Review|last=Windsor|first=Harry|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 14, 2016|accessdate=June 1, 2017}}</ref> * [[GK Films]]<ref name=thr/> * [[LStar Capital]]<ref name=thr/> * Living Films<ref name=thr/> * Material Pictures<ref name=thr/> }} | distributor = Columbia Pictures | released = {{Film date|2016|01|22|United States}} | runtime = 112 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 112:17--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/5th-wave-film | title=''THE 5TH WAVE'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=December 20, 2015 | accessdate=January 19, 2016}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $54 million<ref>{{Cite journal|last=FilmL.A.|first=|date=May 2017|title=2016 Feature Film Study|url=https://www.filmla.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/2016_film_study_WEB.pdf|journal=FilmL.A. Feature Film Study|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> | gross = $109.9 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=5thwave.htm |title=The 5th Wave (2016) |website=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=May 12, 2016}}</ref> }} '''''The 5th Wave''''' is a 2016 American [[Science fiction film|science fiction]] [[action film]] directed by [[J Blakeson]], with a screenplay by [[Susannah Grant]], [[Akiva Goldsman]], and [[Jeff Pinkner]], based on [[Rick Yancey]]’s [[The 5th Wave (novel)|2013 novel of the same name]]. The film stars [[Chloë Grace Moretz]], [[Nick Robinson (American actor)|Nick Robinson]], [[Ron Livingston]], [[Maggie Siff]], [[Alex Roe]], [[Maria Bello]], [[Maika Monroe]], and [[Liev Schreiber]].
Development began in March 2012, when [[Columbia Pictures|Sony]] picked up the film rights to [[The 5th Wave (series)|the trilogy of novels]], with [[Graham King]]'s production company [[GK Films]] and [[Tobey Maguire]]'s Material Pictures. Filming took place in [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]] from October 2014 to January 2015. ''The 5th Wave'' was released on January 22, 2016, in the United States by [[Columbia Pictures]]. It grossed $109 million worldwide against a $54 million budget, and received generally unfavorable reviews from critics.<ref name="MC"/>
==Plot== <!--Per WP:FILMPLOT, this section should be 400-700 words long.--> Ohio high-schooler [[Cassie Sullivan]], armed with an [[M4 carbine]], emerges from the woods to raid an abandoned [[gas station]]. Upon entering, she hears a male voice calling for help. She finds a wounded man, who points a gun at her, but they each put their weapons down. His other hand is under his jacket and as he takes it out, she sees a glint of metal and kills him. He was holding a [[Christian cross]] and the screen cuts to black to show her [[backstory]].
A city-sized alien spaceship is circling Earth, containing extraterrestrials referred to as "The Others". Ten days later, The Others unleash their 1st Wave, an [[electromagnetic pulse]] that permanently destroys all electrical power. The 2nd Wave has The Others manipulate<!--- the method is not explained in the film, but in the novel --> the planet's geology and fault lines, causing [[earthquakes]] and [[megatsunamis]] that destroy coastal cities and islands. For the 3rd Wave, The Others weaponize a strain of [[Avian influenza|avian flu virus]], with birds carrying the infectant across the planet. Cassie's mother is one of the casualties.
Cassie, her father and her younger brother Sam, find a summer camp in use as a refuge in the woods with roughly 300 survivors. A few days later, an Army unit with working vehicles rolls into the camp. The unit's commander, Colonel Vosch, claims there is an imminent threat of a 4th Wave and they will take the children to safety at [[Wright-Patterson Air Force Base]], intending to bring the buses back to retrieve the adults. Cassie is separated from Sam, and witnesses the Army massacring all the adults, her father included.
Cassie scavenges her way toward the base, but is shot in the leg by an unseen shooter and passes out. About a week later, she wakes up in the farmhouse of a young man named Evan Walker, who saved her. Cassie leaves towards the base with Evan, but learns that he is an Other, sent years ago as a sleeper agent and merged his consciousness into a human host. The sleepers roam their designated zones, killing human survivors. Evan admits his humanity was reactivated when he saw her, disagrees with the invasion and lets her leave. He warns that Colonel Vosch and the military are possessed by the consciousness of individual Others.
At the base, the military have used deception and technology to convince the rescued children that the humans outside the base have been possessed. They provide military training to the children, forming them into squads to go on kill missions outside the base. Sam has been placed into a squad led by Ben, a boy Cassie had a crush on, along with Ringer, a tough teenage girl, Dumbo and Teacup. While out on a kill mission, Ringer removes her military implant, causing her to register as an Other-possessed human on the squad's scopes. The squad deduces the plan to have them kill real unpossessed humans, making them the 5th Wave. Ben sends his squad into the woods and returns to base, claiming his squad was killed, for the purpose of retrieving Sam, who was left behind.
Ben confronts Colonel Vosch about child warriors being the 5th Wave and Cassie kills Sergeant Reznik during her one-on-one indoctrination spiel. Ben and Cassie find each other and leave to find Sam. Evan sets off numerous bombs and advises them to quickly find Sam before the destruction of the entire facility. Colonel Vosch and the surviving military evacuate with the human children by military aircraft. Cassie, Ben and Sam escape, with help from Ringer, just as Evan completes the destruction of the base. Ben's squad is reunited and Cassie ponders the strength of hope as humanity's driving force for survival.
==Cast== <!-- star billing, in main "Closing Credits" order, with roles per secondary credits --> <!-- roles as shown on screen of THIS film, NOT extra detail from the books --> {{castlist| * [[Chloë Grace Moretz]] as Cassie Sullivan * [[Nick Robinson (American actor)|Nick Robinson]] as Ben Thomas Parish * [[Ron Livingston]] as Oliver Sullivan * [[Maggie Siff]] as Lisa Sullivan * [[Alex Roe]] as Evan Walker * [[Maria Bello]] as Sergeant Reznik * [[Maika Monroe]] as Ringer * [[Zackary Arthur]] as Sam Sullivan * [[Liev Schreiber]] as Colonel Alexander Vosch * [[Tony Revolori]] as "Dumbo" * [[Talitha Bateman]] as "Teacup" * [[Nadji Jeter]] as "Poundcake" * Alex MacNicoll as "Flintstone" }}
==Production==
===Development=== In March 2012, [[Columbia Pictures]] picked up the film rights to the trilogy, with [[Graham King]] and [[Tobey Maguire]] attached as producers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20696355,00.html|title=Book Review: The 5th Wave|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=May 3, 2013|accessdate=5 December 2013|author=Vilkomerson, Sara}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thewrap.com/j-blakeson-set-to-direct-sony-young-adult-sci-fi-movie-the-5th-wave/|last=Dickey|first=Josh|title=J Blakeson Set to Direct Sony Young-Adult Sci-Fi Movie "The 5th Wave"|accessdate=February 15, 2015|work=The Wrap|date=September 3, 2013}}</ref> On April 15, 2014, it was officially announced that [[Chloë Grace Moretz]] would star as Cassie Sullivan, and that [[J Blakeson]] would direct from a script by [[Susannah Grant]].<ref name="ew">{{cite web |last=Marshall |first=JoJo |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/04/16/chloe-grace-moretz-5th-wave/ |title=Movies Chloe Grace Moretz will be killing aliens in 'The 5th Wave' |work=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=April 16, 2014 |date=April 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kay|first=Jeremy|title=Chloe Grace Moretz to star in alien invasion drama The 5th Wave|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/production/chloe-moretz-to-ride-sonys-wave/5070748.article?blocktitle=HEADLINES&contentID=40295|work=Screen Daily|publisher=Screen International|accessdate=April 16, 2014|date=April 15, 2014}}</ref> From June through August 2014, [[Nick Robinson (American actor)|Nick Robinson]] and [[Alex Roe]] joined the film as male protagonists Ben Parish and Evan Walker, respectively, while [[Liev Schreiber]] was cast as the villain.<ref name="variety">{{cite news |last=McNary |first=Dave |url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/nick-robinson-alex-roe-the-5th-wave-1201253234/ |title=Nick Robinson, Alex Roe Join Chloe Moretz in ‘The 5th Wave’ |date=June 27, 2014 |work=Variety |accessdate=June 28, 2014}}</ref><ref name="wrap">{{cite news|title=Liev Schreiber in Negotiations to Play Villain in Chloe Moretz's ‘The 5th Wave’|url=http://www.thewrap.com/liev-schreiber-in-negotiations-to-play-villain-in-chloe-moretzs-the-5th-wave-exclusive/|accessdate=August 15, 2014|work=The Wrap|date=August 6, 2014}}</ref> Over the following months, [[Maika Monroe]], [[Zackary Arthur]], [[Tony Revolori]], [[Ron Livingston]], [[Maggie Siff]], and Talitha Bateman joined the film.<ref name="thewrap">{{cite news|title=Maika Monroe Joins Chloe Moretz, Nick Robinson in ‘The 5th Wave’|url=http://www.thewrap.com/maika-monroe-joins-chloe-moretz-nick-robinson-in-the-5th-wave/|accessdate=August 15, 2014|work=The Wrap|date=August 11, 2014}}</ref><ref name=siff>{{cite news|last=Ford|first=Rebecca|title='Sons of Anarchy's' Maggie Siff, 'Hart of Dixie' Actress Join 'The 5th Wave'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/sons-anarchys-maggie-siff-hart-742581|accessdate=October 22, 2014|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 21, 2014}}</ref><ref name="hollywoodreporter">{{cite news|last=Ford|first=Rebecca|title='The 5th Wave' Finds Its Sammy (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/5th-wave-finds-sammy-732330|accessdate=October 10, 2014|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=September 15, 2014}}</ref><ref name="revolori">{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title=‘Grand Budapest Hotel’ Actor Tony Revolori Joins Sony’s ‘Fifth Wave’|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/grand-budapest-hotel-tony-revolori-sonys-fifth-wave-1201317504/|accessdate=October 1, 2014|work=Variety|date=September 30, 2014}}</ref>
===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] began on October 18, 2014, in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Rae Johnson|first=Alexa|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2799286/chloe-moretz-dresses-school-uniform-begins-filming-upcoming-sci-fi-drama-5th-wave.html|title=Chloe Moretz dresses in school uniform as she begins filming hotly anticipated sci-fi drama The 5th Wave|accessdate=October 20, 2014|work=Daily Mail|date=October 19, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Lesnick |first=Silas|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=124367|title=Production Begins on The 5th Wave, Starring Chloe Grace Moretz|accessdate=October 24, 2014|work=ComingSoon.net|date=October 23, 2014}}</ref> Three months later, on January 11, a planned explosion of a bus in downtown [[Macon, Georgia]] for the film went awry when it spread wider than planned, blowing out more than forty windows on Cotton Avenue, collapsing ceilings, destroying store fronts, setting one building on fire, and leaving soot on the brick buildings as well. The production company promised to cover all damages caused by the 3:45 am incident, but the work that was done was done badly and remains incomplete twenty-eight months later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macon.com/2015/01/11/3524656/movie-explosion-damages-downtown.html|title=Movie explosion damages downtown Macon buildings|work=macon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/maconsbookstore/status/688025773685497856 |title=Golden Bough Books Twitter |quote=@edunwody @gafmde @5thWaveMovie we expect gold leafing to start any day now but there's unfinished & substandard work on several storefronts}}</ref> Filming officially ended on January 17, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fashionnstyle.com/articles/41514/20150117/the-5th-wave-wraps-filming-chloe-grace-moretz-posts-pics-from-set-sci-fi-flick.htm|archive-url=https://archive.is/20150214114913/http://www.fashionnstyle.com/articles/41514/20150117/the-5th-wave-wraps-filming-chloe-grace-moretz-posts-pics-from-set-sci-fi-flick.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 14, 2015|title='The 5th Wave' Wraps Filming, Chloe Grace Moretz Posts Pics From Set Of Sci-Fi Flick|accessdate=February 13, 2015|work=Fashion&Style|date=January 17, 2015}}</ref>
===Music=== In April 2015, it was announced that [[Henry Jackman]] would compose the music for the film.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2015/04/16/henry-jackman-to-score-the-5th-wave/#comment-187058|title=Henry Jackman to Score ‘The 5th Wave’|accessdate=April 17, 2015|work=Film Music Reporter|date=April 16, 2015}}</ref>
==Release== [[Columbia Pictures]] originally set the film a release date for January 29, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last=Orange|first=B.Alan|url=http://www.movieweb.com/news/the-5th-wave-starring-chloe-moretz-gets-january-2016-release-date|title='The 5th Wave' Starring Chloe Moretz Gets January 2016 Release Date|date=July 14, 2014|work=MovieWeb|accessdate=July 26, 2014}}</ref> On April 30, 2015, they changed the release date from its original release date of January 29, 2016, to an earlier date of January 15, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/5thWaveMovie/status/593869120149573633|title=#5thWaveMovie is coming… even sooner. See it in theaters January 15, 2016.|accessdate=May 1, 2015|publisher=Twitter|date=April 30, 2015}}</ref> However, In December 2015, they pushed back the release date from January 15, 2016, to January 22, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last=Truitt|first=Brian|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2015/12/17/exclusive-excerpt-rick-yancey-the-last-star-novel/77343546/#_=_|title=Exclusive excerpt: Rick Yancey's 'The Last Star'|date=December 17, 2015|work=USA Today|accessdate=December 18, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Kiehne|first=Lawson|url=http://youthindependent.com/5th-wave-monster-high-delayed/|title=‘The 5th Wave’, ‘Monster High’ and More Delayed|date=December 22, 2015|work=Youth Independent News|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref> It was released on January 14, 2016 in Australia, Germany and the Middle East.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2304933/|title=The 5th Wave (2016)|author=MA (Psyboyo)|date=January 22, 2016|work=IMDb}}</ref>
===Marketing=== An international trailer for the film was released on [[Sony Pictures Entertainment|Sony Pictures]]' official [[YouTube]] account on September 1, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fV6mI1fe3gY|title=The 5th Wave Movie - International Sneak Peek|accessdate=September 8, 2015}}</ref>
The film was released for home media on 3 May 2016. The film was released online on various video sites 2 weeks prior to this.
==Reception==
===Box office=== ''The 5th Wave'' grossed $34.9 million in North America and $75 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $109.9 million, against a production budget of $54 million.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=FilmL.A.|first=|date=May 2017|title=2016 Feature Film Study|url=https://www.filmla.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/2016_film_study_WEB.pdf|journal=FilmL.A. Feature Film Study|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><!-- Figures rounded up to nearest hundred thousand. -->
The film was released in North America on January 22, 2016, alongside ''[[Dirty Grandpa]]'' and ''[[The Boy (2016 film)|The Boy]]'', and was projected to gross $10–14 million from 2,908 theaters in its opening weekend.<ref name="preview">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=4147&p=.htm |title='Revenant' Hunts #1 Amid Newcomers, '5th Wave', 'The Boy' and 'Dirty Grandpa' |work= boxofficemojo.com}}</ref> It made $475,000 from its Thursday night screenings and $3.5 million on its first day.<ref name="box office">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/box-office-thursday-late-night-dirty-grandpa-the-fifth-wave-1201688128/ |title=Box Office Thursday Late Nights: ‘Dirty Grandpa’ Knocks In $660K, ‘The Fifth Wave’ Crashes In With $475K |work= deadline.com}}</ref> It went on to gross $10.3 million in its opening weekend, finishing 6th at the box office.<ref name=CinemaScore/>
===Critical response=== On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 15% based on 131 reviews and an average rating of 4.2/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "With unimpressive effects and plot points seemingly pieced together from previous dystopian YA sci-fi films, ''The 5th Wave'' ends up feeling like more of a limp, derivative wriggle."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_fifth_wave/ |title= The 5th Wave (2016) |website=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=December 6, 2017}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 33 out of 100 based on 30 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".<ref name="MC">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-5th-wave |title=The 5th Wave reviews |website=Metacritic |accessdate=February 1, 2016}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "B–" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="CinemaScore">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/box-office-dirty-grandpa-the-5th-wave-the-boy-during-storm-jonas-1201688827/ |title=‘The Revenant’ No. 1, ‘Ride Along’ Skids On Ice |work=deadline.com}}</ref>
Jeffrey M. Anderson of ''[[The San Francisco Examiner]]'' said of the film, "Every plot turn and every line of dialogue has been borrowed from somewhere else, and everything is utterly, totally predictable", noting how the film "steals material from (but does not stop at) the ''[[Twilight (2008 film)|Twilight]]'', ''[[The Hunger Games (film)|Hunger Games]]'' and ''[[Divergent (film)|Divergent]]'' franchises."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Anderson|first1=Jeffrey M.|title=‘5th Wave’ slogs through ridiculous, predictable plot|url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/5th-wave-slogs-through-ridiculous-predictable-plot/|accessdate=26 June 2017|work=The San Francisco Examiner|date=22 January 2016}}</ref> [[Anthony Lane]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' faulted the film as a "marketing wheeze dressed up as an art form, and stupendously summarized by the image of Cassie hurrying through the woods carrying both an assault rifle and a [[Teddy bear]]", adding that the film "appears to have been designed by some crazed [[Oedipus complex|Oedipal]] wing of the [[National Rifle Association|N.R.A.]]"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lane|first1=Anthony|title=The Current Cinema - Tough Girls: "Jane Got A Gun" and "The Fifth Wave"|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/02/01/tough-girls|website=The New Yorker|accessdate=26 June 2017|date=1 February 2016}}</ref>
Rob Vaux of the Sci-Fi Movie Page gave the film one star out of five, saying, "The YA adaptation craze hits a low point with this aimless, purposeless alien invasion story that wastes a fine cast."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scifimoviepage.com/the-5th-wave-movie-review/|title=The 5th Wave — Movie Review|work=Sci-Fi Movie Page}}</ref>{{unreliable source|date=June 2017}} In the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', [[Mick LaSalle]] wrote, "rarely does a movie that fails so utterly start so well", falling apart ahead of the fifth wave. As to a possible trilogy, "if we’re not really vigilant, and look to the skies, and prepare, they’re going to make at least two more of these things. We’ve got to beat back the invasion now".<ref>{{cite web|last=LaSalle|first=Mick|author-link=Mick LaSalle|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/movies/article/The-5th-Wave-at-least-the-apocalypse-6774520.php|title=''The 5th Wave'': At least the apocalypse starts well|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016}}</ref> Eddie Cockrell of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave the film a mixed review, saying, "''The 5th Wave'' is an effectively decent post-apocalyptic, young adult, world-in-the-balance survival thriller" with an "arrestingly original spin on trendy genre tropes", although he suggested that fans of the book may have "issues with what has been edited".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/reviews/the-5th-wave-review-chloe-grace-moretz-1201679744/|title=‘The 5th Wave’ Review: A Decent Adaptation of Rick Yancey’s Novel - Variety|author=Eddie Cockrell|work=Variety}}</ref>
Brian Truitt of ''[[USA Today]]'' gave the film a positive review, stating that it "is an inviting sci-fi invasion" and "nicely stokes the imagination of a new generation of science-fiction movie nerds". He praised Moretz and Robinson as "equally strong" co-leads.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2016/01/21/review-the-5th-wave-movie/79013726/|title=Review: '5th Wave' is an inviting sci-fi invasion|publisher=USA Today|author=Brian Truitt|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref> Shannon Harvey of ''[[The West Australian]]'' also gave the film a positive review, writing, "It’s actually got a lot going for it, from acting prodigy Chloe Grace Moretz as the kind of tough but fragile heroine you can cheer for to handsome production values, several plot twists".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/entertainment/a/30601034/the-5th-wave-too-familiar-to-be-thrilling/|title=The 5th Wave too familiar to be thrilling. - The West Australian|publisher=}}</ref> Michael Patterson of ''[[Moviepilot]]'' gave the film a positive review, calling it a "thrilling story of survival".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://moviepilot.com/reviews/3749541|title=The 5th Wave: A Thrilling Story of Survival!|author=Michael Patterson|date=January 23, 2016|work=moviepilot.com}}</ref>
